switch.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to change from doing or using one thing to doing or using another
switch.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: He switched sides just days before the election.
We want to switch focus away from criticism.
She worked as a librarian before switching to journalism.
Duval could switch easily from French to English.
He switches between TV and theatre work.
switch.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to replace one thing with another, or exchange things
switch.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Tim may switch his BMW for something else.
We’ve switched the meeting from Tuesday to Thursday.
switch something from something to something
It’s not easy to switch clerical workers around.
switch.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if you switch with someone who does the same job as you, you exchange your working times with theirs for a short time
switch.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He asked if we could switch shifts.
Tom said he’d switch with me on Saturday.
switch.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to change the way a machine operates, using a switch
switch.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Three senators switched sides and voted for the ban.
Most of his supporters had switched their allegiance to his rival.
Rod switched channels with the remote control.
Sensing that his victim was going to escape him, he switched tactics.
Laura wasn't interested so he switched his attention to Tessa.
46% of consumers surveyed were likely to switch brands to support companies they saw as socially responsible,
the emphasis switches/is switched to something
The emphasis has switched to defence.
switch.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a piece of equipment that starts or stops the flow of electricity to a machine, light etc when you push it
switch.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Tom flicked the switch, but nothing happened.
She claims she is willing to throw the switch of the electric chair.
Petrol can be chosen at the flick of a switch.
at the flick of a switch
switch.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a complete change from one thing to another
switch.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: More shoppers are making the switch to organic food.
‘Ed’s the only one who’s not eating.’ ‘That’s a switch!’
the switch from agriculture to dairy production
switch.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a piece of railway track that can be moved to allow a train to cross over from one track to another
switch.translation[1].definitions[3].def: a thin stick that bends easily
switch.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: He pressed a switch on the wall and the door opened.
You start the fan by just flipping this switch.
Could a nuclear war really be started by someone just throwing a switch?
He reached for the light switch.
I couldn’t find the on-off switch.
They have reverted to placing the mains power switch at the back of the unit.
The mains switch is located inside a cupboard near the front door.
at the flick/touch of a switch
The advantages of having electricity available at the flick of a switch are obvious.
switch.translation[2].definitions[0].def: in the past, a type of system used for paying for goods and services in the UK, by which customers used a type of plastic card called a debit card, and money was immediately taken out of their bank account. Since 2002, Switch has been replaced by Maestro, the Mastercard brand of debit card.
